author: Jonathan Walker
title: 'I want a parliament vote on Brexit': MP Helen Goodman calls for EU exit pledge
text:
'I want a parliament vote on Brexit': MP Helen Goodman calls for EU exit pledge 15:30, 12 Jul 2016 By Jonathan Walker North East MP Helen Goodman says the House of Commons should debate and vote on when and how the UK leaves the European Union Shares Get daily news by email PA Wire Helen Goodman 
There was anger in the House of Commons as Government Ministers insisted the Queen could take the UK out of the European Union without consulting MPs. 
Bishop Auckland MP Helen Goodman led calls for a guarantee that the Government would allow the House of Commons to debate and have a vote on when and how the UK should leave the EU. 
Theresa May , who becomes Prime Minister on Wednesday, has made it clear that she will proceed with Brexit, saying earlier this week: “There will be no attempts to remain inside the EU, no attempts to rejoin it by the back door, and no second referendum.” 
But there continues to be uncertainty and debate about what the UK’s relationship will be with the EU once we leave. 
And many MPs are demanding that there must be debate in the House of Commons before any changes are agreed. Mrs Goodman tabled an urgent question in the House of Commons asking Ministers whether the Government will seek parliamentary approval before triggering Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty, the mechanism for leaving the EU. 
In response, Cabinet Office Minister John Penrose suggested that a debate in the Commons was likely but not essential because the UK could leave the EU through the royal prerogative - a pronouncement by the Queen, although in practice it would mean the Prime Minister told the Queen to exercise this power. 
Mr Penrose said: “I am sure that everyone will be aware of the debate about whether invoking Article 50 can be done through the royal prerogative, which would not legally require Parliamentary approval, or would require an Act of Parliament because it leads ultimately to repeal or amendment of the European Communities Act 1972. 
“I will leave the lawyers to their doubtless very enjoyable and highly paid disputes. 
“Apart from observing that there are court cases already planned or under way on this issue, so the judges may reach a different view, I simply remark that Government lawyers believe that it is a royal prerogative issue.” Read More What are Theresa May's plans for when she becomes Prime Minister? Here's what you can expect 
But referring to David Cameron , the outgoing Prime Minister, he added: “The Prime Minister has already said that Parliament will have a role, and it is clearly right that a decision as momentous as this one must be fully debated and discussed in Parliament 
“Clearly, the precise format and timing of those debates and discussions will need to be agreed... I strongly doubt that they will be confined to a single debate or a single occasion.” Tens of thousands of people march through central London in a 'March For Europe Event' 
Mrs Goodman said making a decision without a vote in the Commons would take power away from the public when the Leave campaign had promised to give power back. 
She said: “If the royal prerogative is used to trigger Article 50, would that not be a clear breach of the promises made to the public by the Brexiters during the referendum campaign that they would ‘take back control’ and ‘restore parliamentary sovereignty’? 
“How could it be right to initiate negotiations with important and far-reaching significance for citizenship rights, immigration rules, employment and social rights, agriculture, trading relations with the EU and third countries, and Scotland and Northern Ireland, without seeking Parliament’s approval for the aims, objectives and red lines?” 
She added: “The issues at stake are the culmination of 40 years of legislation. Is it not extraordinary to suggest that changes to these areas should not now come back to this House?” 
Chi Onwurah , Labour MP for Newcastle Central, backed calls for a vote in Parliament, saying: “Brexit means Brexit, but there is no agreed definition of what ‘Brexit’ means, apart from the fact that it involves parliamentary sovereignty. 
“Is the Minister seriously proposing that we should undergo such a momentous seismic change as Brexit without its having been defined to the British people before the referendum, or decided on by Parliament after it?” More on the EU Referendum
